text:
:heart:  Regex syntax in DataFrames indexing...

```julia> df = DataFrame(a_1=rand(3), a_2=rand(3), b = rand(3));

julia> df[!, r"^a"]
3×2 DataFrame
 Row │ a_1        a_2
     │ Float64    Float64
─────┼─────────────────────
   1 │ 0.193565   0.47589
   2 │ 0.0611563  0.7215
   3 │ 0.11779    0.672179```
that never even occured to me to try

elements.text: that never even occured to me to try

text: I really don’t like the `!`. It seems wrong
you never need it. Just use `:`

elements.text: you never need it. Just use

text: The fact that it feels wrong is a feature. :stuck_out_tongue: It's there to indicate that you're doing something potentially dangerous (e.g. if you resize the column(s) the parent data frame will be corrupt).

elements.text: The fact that it feels wrong is a feature.
It's there to indicate that you're doing something potentially dangerous (e.g. if you resize the column(s) the parent data frame will be corrupt).

text: Is there an alternative to this that uses hierarchical columns instead of "flat" field names with structure encoded in the strings?

elements.text: Is there an alternative to this that uses hierarchical columns instead of "flat" field names with structure encoded in the strings?

text: <@U72B7LTMX> Not sure I know what you mean, can you expand? I think the answer is no, though you can similar effects using groupby operations. DataFrames is a strictly 2D flat format (though you can do weird things like have columns that contain other dataframes)

elements.text: Not sure I know what you mean, can you expand? I think the answer is no, though you can similar effects using groupby operations. DataFrames is a strictly 2D flat format (though you can do weird things like have columns that contain other dataframes)

text: I think I'm asking about what pandas calls MultiIndex  <https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/advanced.html|https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/advanced.html>

elements.text: I think I'm asking about what pandas calls MultiIndex

text: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/hierarchical-or-multi-index-for-data-frames/17076|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/hierarchical-or-multi-index-for-data-frames/17076> suggests that the answer is no, as does your comment "strictly 2D format". But that regex trick sure makes it possible to get pretty much the same thing.

attachments.title: Hierarchical or multi-index for data frames
attachments.text: Hi, I’ve been looking around for data frame implementations. I found that <https://github.com/JuliaData/DataFrames.jl> does not support a hierarchical or multi-index approach. For clarification, I’m coming from pandas where multi-index is described here: <https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/advanced.html#multiindex-advanced-indexing> After a bit of searching, I am under the impression that multi-index in DataFrames.jl is left out by design. Mentioned in Aug 2017: A spreadsheet-like pivot...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Hierarchical or multi-index for data frames

elements.text: suggests that the answer is no, as does your comment "strictly 2D format". But that regex trick sure makes it possible to get pretty much the same thing.
